monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The statue was designed by Brazilian engineer Heitor da Silva Costa and created by French sculptor Paul Landowski.
The statue’s face was sculpted by Romanian artist Gheorghe Leonida.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: Christ the Redeemer is located atop the Corcovado Mountain in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
The statue stands at an elevation of 700 meters (2,300 feet), overlooking the city and Guanabara Bay.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Construction of Christ the Redeemer began in 1922 and took 9 years to complete.
The statue was officially inaugurated on October 12, 1931.

monumentInformation.title: Who Is It Protected By
details: Christ the Redeemer was declared part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site designation for Rio de Janeiro’s Carioca Landscapes in 2012.
It is maintained by the Archdiocese of Rio de Janeiro and protected by Brazilian heritage organizations.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: The statue was built to symbolize the Christian faith and to commemorate the centenary of Brazil's independence in 1922.
It stands as a universal symbol of peace, hope, and protection for the people of Brazil and visitors from around the world.
